metadata.title: Finite-Time Refined Antidisturbance Velocity Tracking Control for Gimbal System of Control Moment Gyros With Harmonic Drive
metadata.venue: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
metadata.journal: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
metadata.abstract: This article is concerned with high-precision and fast velocity-tracking control for the harmonic drive-based gimbal system of control moment gyro (CMG). As a major challenge in the controller design, the simultaneous presence of multiple matched and mismatched disturbances should be carefully addressed. Specifically, the rotor imbalance inherent in the CMG will cause vibration of the output torque that significantly degrades the tracking performance. On the other hand, the integration of harmonic drives will lead to nonlinear torsional stiffness and introduce additional frictions into the control system. Furthermore, practical tasks such as fast attitude maneuver have posed higher requirement on the rapidity of the antidisturbance control schemes. To overcome the aforementioned difficulties, we propose a finite-time refined antidisturbance velocity tracking controller, which consists of a finite-time harmonic disturbance observer to compensate for the imbalance vibration, an adaptive finite-time extended state observer to handle the remaining disturbances with unknown rate of change, and a finite-time controller to ensure fast convergence of the tracking error. Both numerical simulation and hardware-in-the-loop experimental results show that the proposed scheme outperforms the existing methods in terms of accuracy and rapidity.

Finite-Time Refined Antidisturbance Velocity Tracking Control for Gimbal System of Control Moment Gyros With Harmonic Drive

Finite-Time Refined Antidisturbance Velocity Tracking Control for Gimbal System of Control Moment Gyros With Harmonic Drive
10.1109/TAES.2022.3221911received 17 February 2022; revised 3 June 2022 and 2 Septem-ber 2022; accepted 28 October 2022. Date of publication 14 November 2022; date of current version 9 June 2023.Refereeing of this contribution was handled by X. Wang. This work was supported in part by the National Natural Science Founda-tion of China under Grant 62003016, Grant 61751302, Grant 62073018, Grant 62122007, Grant 62103013, Grant 61627810, and Grant 61603021; and in part by the National Key R&D Program of China under Grant 2020YFA0711200. Authors' addresses: Yangyang Cui, Jianzhong Qiao, and Lei Guo are with
This article is concerned with high-precision and fast velocitytracking control for the harmonic drive-based gimbal system of control moment gyro (CMG). As a major challenge in the controller design, the simultaneous presence of multiple matched and mismatched disturbances should be carefully addressed. Specifically, the rotor imbalance inherent in the CMG will cause vibration of the output torque that significantly degrades the tracking performance. On the other hand, the integration of harmonic drives will lead to nonlinear torsional stiffness and introduce additional frictions into the control system. Furthermore, practical tasks such as fast attitude maneuver have posed higher requirement on the rapidity of the antidisturbance control schemes. To overcome the aforementioned difficulties, we propose a finite-time refined antidisturbance velocity tracking controller, which consists of a finite-time harmonic disturbance observer Manuscript ). (Corresponding authors: Wenshuo Li; Jianzhong Qiao.)0018-9251 © 2022 IEEEto compensate for the imbalance vibration, an adaptive finite-time extended state observer to handle the remaining disturbances with unknown rate of change, and a finite-time controller to ensure fast convergence of the tracking error. Both numerical simulation and hardware-in-the-loop experimental results show that the proposed scheme outperforms the existing methods in terms of accuracy and rapidity.Yangyang Cui received the Ph.D. degree in control theory and control engineering from

NOMENCLATURE ψ f rotor flux linkage. τ f 1 friction torque generated by the PMSM. τ f 2 friction torque within the harmonic drive. τ f 3 friction torque generated by the harmonic drive. θ W /θ F angular position of the wave generator/the flex spline. θ m /θ g angular position of the PMSM/the gimbal. i d /i q stator current of d/q axes. J m /J g inertial moment of the PMSM/the gimbal. k t torque coefficient. L d /L q stator inductance of d/q axes, both equivalent to L N gear reduction ratio. n p number of poles pairs. R s stator resistance. T d vibration torque transmitted from the CMG. T W /T F input torque of the wave generator/the flex spline. T c cogging torque. T f lux flux harmonics. u d /u q stator voltage of d/q axes.


I. INTRODUCTION

Thanks to its large torque amplification rate and low energy consumption, the control moment gyro (CMG) has become the indispensable actuators in attitude control of large spacecrafts and agile maneuver satellite [1], [2], [3], [4]. For example, the Pleiades-II, equipped with four CMGs, is capable of maintaining an earth observation resolution of up to 0.7 m [5]; the Worldview-I and -II satellites can realize slew attitude maneuver with angular velocity of 3 • /s and in the meanwhile meet the imaging requirement of the optical payload [6], [7]. The CMG system consists of a high-velocity rotor and the low-velocity gimbal system. According to the supporting manner of the rotor, the CMGs can be classified into mechanical bearing CMG and magnetically suspended CMG [8], [9]. For both types of CMGs, an output torque will be generated as a result of the so-called gyroscopic effect. That is, a gyroscopic torque is produced when the angular momentum of the rotor is driven by the gimbal to rotate about an axis perpendicular to the spin axis. Hence, the precision of output torque of the CMG is largely dependent on that of gimbal angular velocity [11].

In space missions, the weight and size of the CMG system are usually subject to strict limitations [10]. As a precise torque transmission device, harmonic drives have the advantage of low weight and high torque-to-size ratio and are hence frequently used in the gimbal system to reduce the weight and volume of the torque motor. The reduction of weight and volume, however, comes at a cost of additional uncertainties in the gimbal velocity tracking control system, which is primarily owing to the torsional stiffness nonlinearity and friction torque inherent in the harmonic drives.

For a single-gimbal CMG, the accuracy of velocitytracking control is mainly affected by the vibration resulting from rotor imbalance, friction torque, and unmodeled dynamics [9]. In recent years, antidisturbance control for mechanical system has attracted enormous research interest [13], [14] and many elegant results have been applied to high-precision velocity tracking control of the gimbal system. To address the friction torque, a friction compensation scheme was presented in [15], where the time-delay estimation was adopted to reconstruct the friction torque and a 2-DOF internal model controller was introduced to balance tracking performance and robustness. Adaptive tracking control in the presence heterogeneous disturbances was tackled in [16] via the disturbance observer techniques. In [17], a composite controller was proposed for the gimbal system, where the coupling torque, nonlinear friction, and unmodeled dynamics were considered as a lumped disturbance and eliminated via a novel cascaded extended state observer (ESO). It has been shown that the ESO-based method in [17] can achieve superior velocity tracking performance as compared with the feedback linearization approach. As an improvement to the traditional ESO, a sliding mode ESO was developed in [18] to achieve finite-time compensation of the output-effect disturbance in the PMSM. In [19], a nonlinear dynamic model was established by taking into account the interactions between the rotor and the gyroscopic gimbals, and an adaptive controller consisting of a PI-type dynamic compensator, a feed-forward neural network and a linear observer was proposed for the gimbal system. Considering the rolling element bearing induced disturbances, the output torque of the CMG were modeled and analyzed in [20]. The neural network disturbance observer was also adopted in [21] and combined with backstepping method to construct a composite controller for the gimbal system of CMG.

It is noted that harmonic drives have rarely been considered in the existing literature. In fact, the introduction of harmonic drives would greatly complicate the gimbal control problem as the flexibility effect and additional friction torque that resulted inevitably lead to extra uncertainties in to the entire system. As one of the few results on harmonic drive-based gimbal servo control, the coupling moment and the nonlinear characteristics of harmonic transmission were jointly considered in [10] as a lumped disturbance. On this basis, a disturbance observer based composite controller was developed to achieve disturbance rejection control of the double gimbal system.

Even though the aforementioned results have contributed greatly to improving the precision and robustness of the gimbal system, there are still two challenges that need to be addressed:

1) The heterogeneity of the disturbances has not been fully exploited. For example, the torque vibration caused by rotor imbalance is of periodic type, while the frictions and unmodeled dynamics are both nonlinear and state-dependent. In the existing results, however, the heterogeneous disturbances are treated as a lumped variable where the a prior knowledge on periodicity has not been exploited.

2) The incorporation of harmonic driver for torque transmission has resulted in extra uncertainties with mismatched input channel and unknown upper bound of derivatives. How to achieve fast and refined disturbance rejection under such complicated scenarios is still a theoretical challenge that remains unsettled.

To overcome these shortcomings, the composite hierarchical antidisturbance control (CHADC) framework [22], [23] will be adopted in this article to achieve simultaneous compensation and attenuation of the multiple heterogeneous disturbances in the harmonic drive based gimbal system. A finite-time refined antidisturbance velocity tracking controller will be proposed, which consists of a finite-time harmonic disturbance observer (FTHDO) for real-time reconstruction and compensation of the imbalance vibration, an adaptive finite-time extended state observer (AFTESO) for rejection of the remaining disturbances with unknown rate of change, and a finite-time feedback controller to ensure fast convergence of the tracking error. Compared with the existing results, the contribution of this article can be summarized as follows.

1) Unlike the existing approaches, where the multiple disturbances in the gimbal system are treated as a lumped one [10], [17], two different types of disturbance estimation techniques are employed in our control scheme to handle heterogeneous disturbances according to their specific characteristics: an FTHDO is constructed to compensate for the imbalance vibration which is of periodic nature and an AFTESO is developed to reject the remaining disturbances whose rate of change is unknown; 2) In contrast with the asymptotic stability results obtained in the existing works [10], the finite-time technique employed in the disturbance observer and feedback controller design can ensure faster convergence of the velocity tracking error and hence meet the practical demand in certain space missions such as fast target capture and agile orbital maneuver.

The rest of this article is organized as follows. In Section II, the dynamic model for the harmonic drive-based gimbal system of CMGs is established. The development of the control scheme is introduced in details in Section III. Experimental results are provided in Section IV. Finally Section V concludes this article.


II. DYNAMIC MODELING AND DISTURBANCE ANAL-YSIS

In order to investigate the high-precision velocitytracking control for the harmonic drive-based gimbal system, the dynamic model should be first established. Due to the incorporation of harmonic transmission devices and the CMG, our model consists of two parts: the dynamic model of the harmonic driver and that of the gimbal system. In what follows, we will introduce the dynamic model of the harmonic drive-based gimbal system and carry out disturbance analysis.


A. Model of the Harmonic Drive-Based Gimbal System

Generally speaking, the harmonic driver includes three components: wave generator, flex spline, and circular spline. As depicted in Fig. 1, the elliptically shaped wave generator is connected to the rotating shaft of the PMSM, the circular spline is fixed to the gear housing, and the flex spline is a thin-walled flexible cup with its teeth meshing with those of the circular spline. In the typical configuration of the harmonic drive-based gimbal system, the flex spline is connected to the CMG end and drives the gimbal to rotate.

According to the nomenclatures defined at the beginning of this article, we can write the ideal input-output characteristic of the harmonic drive as follows [24]:
θ W = Nθ F T W = 1 N T F(1)
where N denotes the gear reduction ratio. θ W , θ F , T W , and T F are the angular position of wave generator, the angular position of flex spline, the wave generator's torque, and the flex spline output torque, respectively. It is worth noting that θ F = θ g and θ W = θ m can be measured by the encoders. However, the harmonic drive cannot be simply treated as a rigid gear-reduction device. For example, the nonlinear flexibility of the flex spline and friction torque will introduce nonlinearities into the input-output relationship of the harmonic drive transmission, which is usually referred to as the hysteresis phenomenon in the literature. In addition, kinematic error is also a main source of nonlinear transmission characteristics of the harmonic drive-based gimbal system.

The kinematic error θ is defined as the deviation between the desired and actual angular positions of the flex spline
θ = 1 N θ W − θ F .(2)
Denoting T F 0 as the output torque induced by kinematic error, we have
T F 0 = K h ( θ )(3)
where K h (·) characterizes the torsional stiffness of the harmonic drive. In practice, K h (·) is a nonlinear mapping and can usually be approximated using the following polynomial function:
K h ( θ ) ≈ a 1 θ + a 2 θ 3 + a 3 θ 5 := f h ( θ )(4)
Taking the hysteresis characteristic into account, the total output torque the flex spline can be expressed as [10], [25] 
T F = a 1 θ + a 2 θ 3 + a 3 θ 5 + z(t ) z(t ) = −α 1 d θ dt z(t ) + α 2 d θ dt(5)
where z(t ) is the hysteresis torque; the coefficients a 1 , a 2 , a 3 , α 1 , and α 2 are unknown and need to be identified from practical operation data. Furthermore, the actual relationship between T W and T F can be written as
T W = 1 N T F − τ f 2 .(6)
The torque-equilibrium equation in the motor end can hence be described as
J mθm = T m − τ f 1 − 1 N T F − τ f 2 .(7)
Similarly, the torque-equilibrium equation in the gimbal end can be written as
J gθg = T F − τ f 3 − T d .(8)
Based on the above analysis, we can establish the overall dynamic model of the harmonic drive-based gimbal system with torsional stiffness nonlinearity, friction torque, and hysteresis phenomenon as [9], [26] 
⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ di d dt = 1 L d u d − R s i d + n pθm L q i q di q dt = 1 L q u q − R s i q − n pθm L d i d − n pθm ψ f T F = a 1 θ + a 2 θ 3 + a 3 θ 5 + z(t ) z(t ) = −α 1 d θ dt z(t ) + α 2 d θ dt J mθm = k t i q + ( 1 N τ f 2 − 1 N T F − T c − T f lux − τ f 1 ) J gθg = T F − τ f 3 + T d .
. (9) 


B. Disturbance Analysis

In this section, we will carry out detailed disturbance analysis according to the system model (9). For the harmonic drive-based gimbal system, the disturbances that affect the accuracy of velocity tracking come mainly from three aspects: the motor side (the flux harmonics, the cogging torque, and the friction torque), the gimbal side (the torque vibration induced by rotor imbalance and the friction torque), and the harmonic transmission device (the hysteresis characteristics and the friction torque).

On the motor side, the flux harmonics should be considered. In this article, the following model is adopted for the flux harmonics [26] 
T flux = 3 2 n p i q ∞ i=1 ψ f i cos (6iθ me )(10)
where ψ f i is the amplitude of the 6ith harmonic component; θ me is the electrical angle of the PMSM. As for the cogging torque, a commonly used disturbance model is [27] (11) where T ci is the amplitude of the ith harmonic component and N c is the least common multiple between the number of slots and pole pairs. On the gimbal side, the rotor imbalance in the gimbal system will lead to torque vibration of the harmonic reducer. The torque vibration is a periodic signal and can be described as [28], [29] ⎧ ⎨
T c = ∞ i=1 T ci sin (iN c θ me )⎩ T dx = U d 2 cos ( t + ϕ d ) T dy = U d 2 sin ( t + ϕ d ) T dz = 0 (12) where U d = m d r d h d , m d is the lumped unbalanced quality;
and ϕ d are the angular frequency and the initial phase of the torque vibration, respectively.

Furthermore, the nonlinear friction torques exist in the motor side, the gimbal side, and the harmonic transmission devices. The Coulomb and viscous components of the friction torque can be described by the Stribeck model [30] 
τ f i = f ci − f si − f ci e − ω i ω si 2 sign (ω i ) + B i ω i (13)
where f ci > 0 are the Coulomb friction, f si > 0 represent the stiction torque, ω si denote the Stribeck velocity, and B vi are the viscous friction coefficient.

It is worth noting that, among the aforementioned multiple disturbances, the torque vibration caused by rotor imbalance is the most significant one in terms of both magnitude and effect on velocity tracking [7], [11]. Therefore, the torque vibration is the main disturbance to be addressed in our work. In order to achieve refined compensation of the torque vibration, the dynamic model (12) should be fully exploited, which will be elaborated in Section III-B.

According to the aforementioned disturbance analysis, we can rewrite the system model (9) as
⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ di d dt = 1 L d u d − R s i d + n pθm L q i q di q dt = 1 L q u q − R s i q − n pθm L d i d − n pθm ψ f T F = a 1 θ + a 2 ( θ ) 3 + a 3 ( θ ) 5 + ρ(t ) ρ(t ) = −α 1 d θ dt ρ(t ) + α 2 d θ dt J mθm = k t i q − B mθm − a 1 N θ + d m d m = 1 N τ f 2 − T c − T f lux − 1 N (a 2 ( θ ) 3 + a 3 ( θ ) 5 + ρ(t )) − f cm − f sm − f cm e − ωm ωsm δ sign (ω m ) J gθg = a 1 θ − B gθg + d g d g = −T d .
. (14) Before proceeding to the main results of this article, the following assumption and lemmas will be introduced at first. ASSUMPTION 1 As a common practice, the lumped disturbance d m is assumed to be differentiable and norm-bounded. Furthermore, the upper bound of the derivative of d m is unknown. That is,
d m ≤ η m , ḋ m ≤ h m
where η m is a known positive constant, h m is an unknown positive constant.

REMARK 1 In practical engineering, the gimbal system generally works at ultra-low velocity. Hence, the lumped disturbance d m will not change rapidly and can therefore be treated as a derivative-bounded variable. However, the dynamics of d m are quite complicated as the evolution models of T f lux , T c and τ f i are determined by many unknown parameters, which may change with the working conditions of the gimbal system [see (10), (11), and (13)]. As a result, it is rather difficult to determine the upper bound ofḋ m in advance, making the existing results that rely on a predetermined upper bound not applicable anymore [31]. To overcome this challenge, an AFTESO will be developed in Section III to achieve finite-time disturbance compensation without a prior knowledge on the upper bound ofḋ m .

LEMMA 1 (SEE [32], [33]) Consider the systeṁ
x(t ) = f (x, t ), x ∈ R n , f (x, 0) = 0.(15)
Suppose there exist a Lyapunov functionV 1 (x), positive constants 0 < τ 1 < 1, l 1 > 0 and l 2 > 0, such thaṫ
V 1 (x) + l 1V1 (x) + l 2V τ 1 1 (x) ≤ 0.(16)
Then, the origin of system (15) is finite-time stable, and the settling time is given as
t 1 ≤ 1 l 1 (1 − τ 1 ) ln l 1V 1−τ 1 1 (x 0 ) + l 2 l 2(17)
whereV 1 (x 0 ) is the initial value ofV 1 (x).

LEMMA 2 (SEE [34]) Consider the system (15). Suppose that there exist a Lyapunov functionV 2 (x), positive constants 0 < τ 2 < 1 and l 3 > 0, such thaṫ
V 2 (x) + l 3V τ 2 2 (x) ≤ 0.(18)
Then, the origin of system (15) is finite-time stable, and the settling time is given as
t 2 ≤V 1−τ 2 2 (x 0 ) l 3 (1 − τ 2 )(19)
whereV 2 (x 0 ) is the initial value ofV 2 (x).

LEMMA 3 (SEE [35]) Consider the system (15). Suppose that there exist a Lyapunov functionV 3 (x), positive constants 0 < τ 3 < 1, l 4 > 0, and χ > 0, such thaṫ Then, the trajectory of system (15) is practical finite-time stable, and the settling time is given as
V 3 (x) + l 4V τ 3t 3 ≤V 1−τ 3 2 (x 0 ) l 4 ϑ 0 (1 − τ 3 )(21)
where 0 < ϑ 0 < 1 andV 3 (x 0 ) is the initial value ofV 3 (x).


III. COMPOSITE VELOCITY-TRACKING CONTROLLER DESIGN

In this section, as illustrated in Fig. 2, a composite velocity-tracking controller will be developed. The proposed composite controller consists of an FTHDO for imbalance vibration rejection, an AFTESO to compensate for the lumped disturbances on the motor side, and a finite-time backstepping controller (FTBSC) to ensure fast convergence of the tracking error. The three components will be elaborated in what follows.


A. AFTESO Design

To estimate the unknown lumped disturbance d m , the AFTESO will be adopted. Different from the traditional ESO design, an AFTESO will be developed where the adaptive law is employed to deal with the unknown upper bound ofḋ m , and the finite-time technique is used to ensure high convergence rate of the disturbance estimation error. Defining an auxiliary variable z m , the AFTESO is designed as
⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ω m = k t J m i q − B m J m ω m − a 1 J m N θ + 1 J md m + β m0ω + υ ṁ z m = −β m2 k t i q + (β m2 J m − B m ) ω m +z m − a 1 N θ + ĥ m + δ 1 sign (υ m ) d m = z m + β m2 J m ω m ,(22)
where υ m = β m1 sign(ω m ) and δ 1 is positive constant. The adaptive law is designed aṡ
h m = J m υ m − δ 2ĥm(23)
where δ 2 is positive constant Defining the estimation error of the AFTESO (22) as
ω m = ω m −ω m d m = d m −d m(24)
the error dynamic equation can be written as
ω m = −β m0ωm + 1 J md m − υ ṁ d m =ḋ m − β m2dm − ĥ m + δ 1 sign (υ m ) .(25)
In order to ensure finite-time convergence of the error system (25), the gains in the AFTESO should be selected according to the following theorem. THEOREM 1 For the AFTESO system (22), the gains are selected such that
⎧ ⎨ ⎩ β m0 > 0 β m1 = 1 J m η m + d m + δ 0 β m2 > 0(26)
where the constant δ 0 > 0. Then, the disturbance estimation error of d m will converge to the region m in finite time.

PROOF The proof procedures are divided into the following there steps.

Step1: In Step1, we will prove thatω m can converge the zero in a finite time. Consider the following Lyapunov function:
V 1 = 1 2ω 2 m .(27)
Taking the time-derivative of (27) giveṡ
V 1 =ω m d m J m − β m0ωm − υ m ≤ −β m0 ω m 2 − β m1 − d m J m ω m ≤ −β m0 ω m 2 − 1 J m J m β m1 − d m − d m ω m ≤ −β m0 ω m 2 − 1 J m (η m + δ 0 − d m ) ω m ≤ −2β m0 V 1 − √ 2 δ 0 J m V 1 2 1 .(28)
According to Lemma 1, the errorω m will converge to zero in finite-time
T 1 ≤ 1 β m0 ln( √ 2J m β m0 V 1 2 1 (0)+δ 0 δ 0
). Thereafter, ω m =ω m = 0 is hold. Therefore, based on the equivalent out injection principle [31], [36], it can be concluded from (25) thatd m is equivalent to J m υ m , (d m ) eq = J m υ m namely.

Step2: Consider the following Lyapunov function:
V 2 = 1 2d 2 m + 1 2h 2 m .(29)
Taking the time-derivative of (29) giveṡ
V 2 =d mḋ m +h mḣm =d m ḋ m − β m2dm − ĥ m + δ 1 sign (υ m ) +h m ḣ m −ḣ m ≤ − β m2 d m 2 + h m d m − ĥ m + δ 1 d m sign (υ m ) −h mḣm ≤ − β m2 d m 2 − δ 1 −h m d m −h mḣm .(30)
Substituting the adaptive law (23) into (30), one haṡ
V 2 ≤ − δ 1 −h m d m −h m J m υ m − δ 2ĥm = − δ 1 d m + δ 2hmĥm ≤ − δ 1 d m + δ 2 h 2 m 2 −h 2 m 2 = − δ 1 d m − δ 2 2 h m + δ 2 2 h m 2 + h m − h m 2 ≤ − min √ 2δ 1 , δ 2 √ 2 V 1 2 2 + δ 2 2 h m 2 + 1 4 ≤ − min √ 2δ 1 , δ 2 √ 2 V 1 2 2 + δ 2 + 4δ 2 h 2 m 8 .(31)
Therefore, based on the Lemma 3, the estimation error d m can be driven into a bounded set m in finite time
T 2 = T 1 + 2V 1 2 2 (T 1 ) γ 0 min{ √ 2δ 1 , δ 2 √ 2 } with 0 < γ 0 < 1, where m = d m ∈ R n d m ≤ 0 (32) with 0 = (δ 2 +4δ 2 h 2 m ) 8(1−γ 0 ) min{ √ 2δ 1 , δ 2 √ 2 }
. The proof is completed.

REMARK 2 Compared with traditional ESOs, higher convergence rate can be achieved by the proposed scheme due to the introduction of the switching term (ĥ m + δ 1 )sign(υ m ). However, a negative effect induced by the switching term is the so-called chattering phenomenon, which leads to deterioration of the actuator. In order to restrict the impact of the switching term, an overly large gain should be avoided for the sign function. In this article, an adaptive law (23) is adopted to estimateĥ m in real-time, thereby maintaining the fast convergence property of the observer and in the meanwhile reducing the chattering phenomenon.


B. FTHDO Design

According to the disturbance analysis, it can be concluded that d g can be described as a harmonic signal with known frequency, unknown amplitude, and unknown phase. Therefore, d g can be described by the following neutrally stable exogenous system:
ξ g = W g ξ g d g = V g ξ g(33)
where
W g = 0 g − g 0 2×2 and V g = [1 0] 1×2 .
To estimate d g , the FTHDO is designed as ⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ω g = 1 J g a 1 θ − B g ω g +d g + β g0ωg + υ g ż g = W g − β g2 V g z g + β g2 J g ω g −β g2 a 1 θ − B g ω g + β g3 sign υ g ξ g = z g + β g2 J g ω ĝ d g = V gξg (34) The term is designed as υ g = β g1 sign(ω g −ω g ). β g0 , β g1 , β g2 = β g21 β g22 2×1 , and β g3 = β g31 β g32 2×1 are the gains of (34).

Defining the estimation errors of (34) as
ω g = ω g −ω g ξ g = ξ g −ξ g(35)
the error dynamic equation for the FTHDO can be written as
ω ġ ξ g ė g = − β g0 J g 1 J g V g 0 2×1 W g − β g2 V g A g ω g ξ g e g − 1 J g υ g β g3 sign υ g φ g .(36)
In order to ensure finite-time convergence of the error system (36), the gains in the FTHDO should be selected according to the following theorem. THEOREM 2 For the FTHDO system (34), the gains are selected such that
⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ β g0 > 0 β g1 = − β g3 +δ 3 λ max (Ag) + δ 4 λ max W g − β g2 V g < 0, β g21 > 0 β g31 > 0 (37)
where δ 3 and δ 4 are all positive constants. Then, the estimation error of d g will converge to the origin in finite time T 5 .

PROOF The proof procedure is split into three steps.

Step1: Consider the following Lyapunov function:
V 3 = 1 2 e T g e g .(38)
The time-derivative of V 3 can be calculated aṡ
V 3 = e T g A g e g − φ g ≤ λ max A g e g 2 − β g1 J g ω g −ξ T g β g3 sign υ g ≤ λ max A g e g 2 + β g3 e g = − √ 2 −λ max A g e g − β g3 V 1 2 3 .(39)
If e g ≥ − β g3 +δ 3
λ max (A g ) = 1 , thenV 3 ≤ − √ 2δ 3 V 1 2
3 . According to Lemma 2, e g can be driven into an attraction region g = {e g , e g ≤ 1 } within finite time
T 3 = √ 2 δ 3 V 1 2 3 (0).
Step2: Consider the following Lyapunov candidate:
V 4 = 1 2ω 2 g .(40)
The time-derivative of V 4 can be calculated aṡ
V 4 =ω g − β g0 J gω g + 1 J g V gξg − 1 J g υ g ≤ − β g0 J g ω g 2 + 1 J g e g ω g − 1 J g β g1 ω g ≤ − β g0 J g ω g 2 + 1 J g e g − β g1 ω g .(41)
It is worth noting that if β g1 = 1 + δ 4 with δ 4 is a positive constant, one can obtain thaṫ
V 4 ≤ −2 β g0 J g V 4 − √ 2 J g δ 4 V 1 2 4 .(42)
According to Lemma 1, the estimation errorω g will converge to zero within finite time
T 4 = T 3 + J g β g0 ln √ 2β g0 V 1 2 4 (T 3 )+δ 4 δ 4
. After that,ω g =ω g = 0 holds all the time. As a result, based on the equivalent out injection principle [31], [36], it can be concluded thatd g is equivalent to υ g .

Step3: Now, the Lyapunov function is constructed as
V 5 = 1 2d 2 g .(43)
The time-derivative of V 5 can be calculated aṡ

When β g21 > 0 and β g31 > 0, eq. (44) can be rewritten asV
5 ≤ − √ 2β g31 V 1 2 5 .(45)
Based on the Lemma 2, it can be concluded thatd g will converge to zero within finite time
T 5 = T 4 + √ 2V 1 2 5 (T 4 ) β g31
. In other words, within T 6 = max{T 2 , T 5 }, the estimation errors d m andd g will converge to 0 and 0, respectively. REMARK 3 According to Theorems 1 and 2, it can be concluded that, for the estimation errors under the proposed AFTESO and FTHDO, the convergence rate is related to the gains (26) and (37), where the maximum convergence time can be prescribed. This is particularly favorable for some real-time missions with rapidity requirement.


C. Finite-Time Back-Stepping Controller Design

The object of the FTBSC design is to drive ω g to converge to ω * g within a finite time. In order to deal with both matched disturbance and mismatched disturbance simultaneously, the following coordinate change should be first performed for system (14) ⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ẋ

where x 1 = θ g , x 2 = ω g , x 3 = θ m , and x 4 = ω m . THEOREM 3 Consider the closed-loop control system described as (46) and suppose that Assumption 1 holds. If the FTBSC is designed as

The controller is designed as Therefore, theV 9 can be obtained as [37]

Since 1 2 < p+q 2q < 1, based on the Lemma 2, it can concluded that the velocity-tracking error can be driven into zero within a finite time. REMARK 4 Different from the existing results [12], [17], a dual disturbance observer strategy is adopted to make full use of the specific characteristics of heterogeneous disturbances. Specifically, the AFTESO and FTHDO are developed to estimate the lumped disturbance d m and the harmonic disturbance d g , respectively. In both the AFTESO and the FTHDO, finite-time estimation techniques are employed to ensure fast convergence of the estimation errors. On this basis, an FTBSC is developed to compensate for the effect of multiple matched and mismatched disturbances and ensure fast convergence of the velocity tracking error. It should be noted that, due to the introduction of fractionalorder term in the FTBSC, the control force is likely to be overly large when the error terms ε i in (61) are close to zero.   REMARK 5 Theorems 1-3 are sufficient to guarantee finitetime convergence of the disturbance estimation errors and velocity tracking errors. In addition to satisfying Theorems 1-3, the parameters of the composite controller should also be selected according to their relationship with the closed-loop performance. Specifically, the convergence rate of the AFTESO will increase with a larger β m1 and that of the FTHDO will increase with a larger β g3 . However, the switching terms will dominate the observer dynamics when β m1 and β g3 grow too large, leading to severe chattering problem. Hence, there is a compromise between increasing convergence rate and reducing chattering phenomenon when tuning the parameters. Besides, the "trial and error" procedure as well as some related references, e.g. [29], [31], [35], [38], can also serve as guidance in the parameter selection.   


IV. NUMERICAL SIMULATIONS

In this section, numerical simulation is carried out to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method. The main parameters of the gimbal system used in our simulation are shown in Table I. The velocity tracking performance of the proposed method will be compared to those of the PI, the PI+ESO, and the FTBSC+ESO. In order to provide a fair comparison, the same PI control gains are adopted in PI and PI+ESO, the same ESO gains are used in PI+ESO and FTBSC+ESO, and the same FTBSC gains are shared by FTBSC+ESO and the proposed control law. For all the fractional-order terms, we have adopted p = 1 and q = 3. Detailed controller parameters have been presented in Table II for   The following four scenarios will be considered in our simulation:

Case I: ω * g is constant with d m . Fig. 3 shows the estimation performance of the AFTESO. In fact, due to the capability of the AFTESO in real-time compensation of d m , the PI+ESO has outperformed PI in all the four scenarios. On the other hand, the proposed approach is expected to degenerate into the FTBSC+ESO method in the absence of d g . This is confirmed by the simulation results depicted in Fig. 4. It can be found from Fig. 4 that the tracking performance of the proposed method is comparable to that of the FTBSC+ESO. Besides, both the proposed method and the FTBSC+ESO have greatly outperformed the PI+ESO, which demonstrates the superiority of the proposed finitetime backstepping control law over the conventional PI.

Case II: ω * g is constant with d m and d g . In the presence of d g , the proposed FTHDO is expected to play a role in real-time disturbance estimation and compensation. Fig. 5 shows the estimation performance of the FTHDO. The velocity tracking performance is shown in Fig. 6. It is clear that both the proposed method and the FTBSC+ESO have outperformed the other two methods in terms of convergence rate. Furthermore, the proposed method has achieved much lower steady-state error as compared to the other three: almost no fluctuation is observed from its velocity tracking error, which demonstrates the effect of the FTHDO. Case III: ω * g is sinusoidal with d m . When the desired trajectory is sinusoidal, the velocity tracking performance has been shown in Fig. 7. The results are similar to those of Case I, which indicates that the proposed approach is effective in tracking different types of desired trajectory.

Case IV: ω * g is sinusoidal with d m and d g . The tracking performance in this case is plotted in Fig. 8. It can be seen that the proposed method exhibits superior velocity tracking performance over FTBSC+ESO, which again confirms the effectiveness of the FTHDO. Furthermore, due to the use of finite-time strategy and backstepping design, the setting time and overshoot of the proposed method and the FTBSC+ESO are much smaller than those of the PI+ESO.

Summarizing the simulation results, it can be concluded that: 1) the AFTESO can be used to reject the lumped disturbance d m , which is demonstrated by the superiority 


V. EXPERIMENTAL VALIDATION

In order to further verify the effectiveness of the proposed method in practical situations, hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) experiments are carried out where the proposed method is compared against the PI, the PI+ESO, and the FTBSC+ESO approaches. The experimental platform is illustrated in Fig. 9, which comprises 1) a real-time simulator with 2.7 GHz basic frequency and VxWorks real-time operating system; 2) a display module; 3) an HS0150AE-P22S servo drives with 1.5 KW rated power; 4) a host computer with Windows operating system, Simulink-based servo control design and automatic code generation capability; 5) the torque sensors with an output range of 5 KNm ∼ 15 KNm and the angular velocity sensor with 60 pulses per revolution; 6) a load motor; and 7) the PMSM with 1.5 KW rated power. The step size of the semiphysical experiment is set as 0.0001 s. The harmonic drive-based gimbal system, control algorithm, and the imbalance disturbance d g are generated in the C code by the host computer. The d m and the measurement noise are obtained from HIL. The key parameters of the gimbal system are the same as those shown in Table I. The controller parameters used in our experimental test are the same as those shown in Table II, except that the fractional-order terms are not used in the backstepping control laws. The four scenarios, as mentioned in the previous section, are considered in the experiment. The experimental results are presented in Figs. 10-13. It can be observed that the experimental results essentially coincide with those obtained from numerical simulation. The slight discrepancies from the simulation results are probably owing to the additional disturbances and noise induced by the actual PMSM. Specifically, the steady-state velocity tracking error does not converge to zero due to the influence of the power supply ripple, which has not been taken into account in the controller design. Despite the output ripples, experimental results have demonstrated the superiority of the proposed FTHDO over the FTBSC+ESO in harmonic disturbance rejection. Besides, the lower steady-state error of the PI+ESO as compared to that produced by the PI has verified the effectiveness of the AFTESO. Furthermore, the proposed FTBSC scheme exhibits superior transient performance as compared with the PI controller (the setting time reduced by around 70%), in all the four scenarios.


VI. CONCLUSION

In this article, the velocity tracking control problem for the harmonic drive-based gimbal system of the CMG is studied. A novel composite controller, consisting of an FTHDO, an AFTESO, and an FTBSC has been developed to achieve finite-time stabilization under multiple matched and mismatched disturbances. The advantages of the proposed control scheme are two-fold: 1) By making full use of the prior information of multiple disturbances, the matched and mismatched disturbances can be simultaneously estimated by the dual-observer, which is less conservativeness as compared to the ESO method; 2) On the basis of disturbance estimation, a composite controller with finite-time convergence properties is proposed to ensure fast and accurate tracking performance of the gimbal system. Both simulation and HIL experimental results have verified the superiority of the proposed control strategy over the PI, the PI+ESO, and the FTBSC+ESO in terms of convergence time, steady-state error, and antidisturbance performance. As for future research directions, it is interesting to investigate how to incorporate the proposed control method into the prescribed performance control framework [39], [40], [41], which offers a systematic way to deal with practical constraints such as settling time and overshoot.
